ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

BOUNDARIES DELINEATION COMMITTEE
(Report)


    1. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Prime Minister when will the Boundaries Delineation Committee's Report be published.

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng) (for the Prime Minister): Sir, the general elections need not be held until August next year. The Prime Minister has not formed the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee yet.

Column: 1741



    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): May I ask the Minister, why does he say that the elections need not be held until August next year? What does he consider the life of Parliament to be, and when does it begin?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, the life of Parliament is five years.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: When does it commence?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: I think Mr Jeyaretnam was here. He should remember.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Is he aware that Parliament came into being on 2nd January 1997, Members were elected to Parliament on 2nd January, and Ministers were appointed soon after that, and they should have been Members of Parliament before they were appointed Ministers? So was Parliament not already in existence from 2nd January?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, Mr Jeyaretnam knows his law better than I do. We had elections on 2nd January 1997. We did not have Parliament sitting until May 1997.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister whether he has taken any advice or consultation with the UK Parliament as to when the term of Parliament commences, whether it commences from the election of Members or from the time of its sitting?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, I am not sure the UK experience is totally relevant to us. As far as we are concerned, our laws are such that Parliament was convened in May 1997 and the life of Parliament is five years.

    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, the Minister says the work has not started yet. When will the Committee start its work?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, the Committee would only start its work when it is appointed.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: When will the Committee be appointed?

Column: 1742



    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, I do not know. The Prime Minister has not decided.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, how many members will be in the Committee?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, as the Committee has not been decided and when it will be formed has also not been decided, I really cannot tell him how many members will be in the Committee.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, the Minister does not seem to know all the three questions I asked. I do not know whether it is worthwhile continuing.

    Mr S. Iswaran (West Coast): Question No. 2, Sir.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: I just have one final question.

    Mr Deputy Speaker: I think we have exhausted Question No. 1, Mr Jeyaretnam.

Column: 1742

ECONOMIC AND UNEMPLOYMENT OUTLOOK
(Assessment)


    2. Mr S. Iswaran asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) what is his assessment of Singapore's economic and unemployment outlook for the second half of 2001; and (b) whether off-Budget measures are warranted in light of recent negative economic data.

    3. Mr Tay Beng Chuan asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether the Government will implement an off-Budget cost cutting package immediately to save businesses and jobs in anticipation of the worsening economic crisis.

    4. Mr Zulkifli Bin Baharudin asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether the Government will consider introducing off-Budget measures in view of the weak economic situation.

    5. Mr Noris Ong Chin Guan asked the Minister for Trade and Industry if he has any plans to accelerate the implementation of infrastructure projects in

Column: 1743

the pipeline of the various Ministries, as a means to provide more opportunities for local businesses and indirectly more employment opportunities for Singaporeans.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, with your permission, I would like to answer Questions Nos. 2, 3, 4 and 5 together as they are on the same issue.

    Mr Deputy Speaker: Yes.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Thank you. The Singapore economy shrank by 0.8% in the second quarter, following the weaker external environment. The slow-down is more rapid than what we had earlier expected.

    All the major economies have slowed sharply. US growth in the first quarter was revised downwards significantly from the initial estimate of 2% to 1.2%, as companies run down inventories at a much faster pace. The EU has also slowed significantly while the Japanese economy is near or may be in recession.

    At the same time, the global electronics industry has deteriorated even more sharply in the last few months. Global semiconductor sales fell by 29% in April and May, down from -4.4% in the first quarter this year and +22% growth in the fourth quarter of last year. For the whole year, industry analysts at Gartner Dataquest expect the industry to shrink by 20% to 25%.

    The negative environment has a large impact on Singapore's growth as external demand accounts for 80% of our total demand. In particular, our manufacturing sector has declined by 10.9% in May, and is expected to remain weak in the second half. Export-oriented services have also slowed as demand from regional economies fell. We have therefore revised our growth forecast this year down to 0.5% to 1.5%.

Column: 1744



    We can expect unemployment to worsen. The number of workers retrenched rose sharply to about 3,200 in the first quarter of this year, up from an average of 1,900 in the last three quarters of 2000. We expect more retrenchment in the second half of the year as companies, which were holding onto workers in anticipation of a quick turnaround, begin to shed off workers. Already, we have seen more companies putting their workers on shorter work-week and compulsory leave. There has also been a significant fall in job advertisements in recent months. Anecdotally, I think all of us would have heard or received feedback from friends and relatives that there is a fear that they may lose their jobs because of the retrenchment that they see going on around them.

    In view of the sharper than expected downturn, the Government intends to implement some specific measures to cushion its impact on companies and workers. However, this will not be like the $10 billion package in 1998. The 1998 package was necessary to restore Singapore's competitiveness following the Asian financial crisis and the sharp devaluation of regional currencies. The current downturn is a cyclical slowdown caused by a severe drop in external demand, especially in electronics. We are encouraging Ministries to speed up their development projects, but we should be realistic that such pump priming would only be of marginal benefit; leakage is high and it would not be able to offset the drastic fall in external demand. The objective of the measures we are working on this time is to ease the burden on businesses and workers, while we await the recovery of the US economy and the global electronics industry.

    Part of the 1998 package is still in place, as some of the cost-cutting measures in that package have not been fully lifted. This includes the 4% point reduction in employers' CPF contribution, the cut in foreign worker levies, and JTC and HDB rental rebates. In addition, at the last Budget, the Minister for Finance lowered corporate and property tax rates, and

Column: 1745

introduced various rebates and CPF top-ups to help individuals and workers.

    We are finalising the new measures. I expect to announce them to this House at the end of the month.

    Mr Zulkifli Bin Baharudin (Nominated Member): Sir, the Minister mentioned that this problem is cyclical in nature. I would like to ask the Minister whether this could, in fact, lead to more severe structural problems as there could be more hollowing out of our economy, and therefore lead to more severe unemployment and retrenchment than earlier expected.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: The structural shifts have been going on for some time. This is the reason why we have been pressing on with investing in R&D and worker upgrading. Part of the reason is, of course, the emergence of China into the global market. And as hundreds of millions of Chinese workers who are hardworking and not without ability join the global labour market, there will be downward wage pressure all around. Those who are unable to upgrade find themselves under great pressure.

    For example, in India, Chinese consumer products are really cutting the ground from under Indian manufacturers. When I spoke to the Vietnamese Trade Minister recently, he was quite worried about the way Chinese products are fast entering the Vietnamese market. They told me that a Chinese motorcycle with as good or better quality cost only one-third of a Vietnamese motorcycle. And we see this now all over, how Chinese products are lowering the cost of clothing, of handbags, of all kinds of things. All over Singapore now, you are seeing sprouting up $2 stores and they are carrying mostly Chinese products.

    While this keeps cost down, this also presents challenges to some of the industry sectors. So the only way for us to maintain our high wage levels in Singapore is to press on with the education of our young, with worker training and upgrading, improving system efficiency and investing in R&D. And if we

Column: 1746

continue to do that, we should be able to hold our own in the sectors that we are very good at. For example, if you look at the wafer fabs, I think we remain very competitive, and there are a number of investments on stream, they will probably be delayed, but I think our basic competitiveness in semi-conductors remains unchanged. For disk drives, we face a challenge, and the more labour intensive lines we are losing to Penang and China. But last year, when Seagate decided to close down its disk drive operation in Penang and shed off 5,000 workers, they reconfigured their production so that the labor intensive portions went to Wuxi and Shenzhen in China, while the higher value-added and the more automated bits were reconcentrated in Singapore, where we have been helping them to build the 'factory of the future', which means highly automated lines, you design a product with a view to producing it, and therefore enabling you to automate many of the processes. So sector after sector, we have got to keep on pushing on with restructuring and ensuring that despite competition from other countries, we are able to maintain our high wage levels.

    This cyclical downturn may accentuate the process but we should not mix up the two separate tendencies.

    Mr Iswaran: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, there is a perception in the market that pump priming and other measures to boost domestic demand may help offset some of the impact of the negative external demand. The Minister has explained why he does not think this might work. Could he elaborate on this so that everybody will have a better understanding?

    The other point is that the low end of Government's forecast of 0.5% for GDP growth this year is very similar to that which Singapore experienced in 1998 which prompts many to ask the question why a similar order of magnitude of Government off-Budget measures is not warranted. Could the Minister please elaborate?

Column: 1747



    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: We had 4.6% growth for the first quarter. Flash estimate for second quarter is -0.8%. If we anticipate 1% at the end of the year, that means for the remaining six months, for the second half, we are anticipating the economy to be flat. And 0.5% to 1.5% projection for the whole year means that we are anticipating the second half to be somewhere in between -1% and +1%. The following quarter, we expect the downturn to continue because, if you look at non-oil retained imports, which is a pretty good indicator of what is going to happen in the next one to three months, it remains sharply negative, -16% or 17% last month. So there is near certainty that the next quarter will remain negative. But when it comes to the fourth quarter, we are not sure.

    If you listen to the American Treasury Secretary, he said he is quite confident that the US would be able to achieve 2% in the fourth quarter which means that things would begin to look up then. Stanley Fischer of the IMF made similar noises. And there are some indications that consumer confidence has picked up, that orders have begun to show more life. So we are not sure what the fourth quarter would look like.

    While we should not be unduly optimistic, we should also not be excessively pessimistic. If you look on the horizon, yes, there are dark clouds, but there are also silver linings. If you ask me where we are at now - I do not want to go into the details of the package because that would be announced when they have been finalised at the end of the month - it is obviously raining, and the rain will get heavier. This is not a passing shower. But we should not assume that it is going to be a full-blown thunder storm. It may not be. We should get our umbrellas ready and try to stay as dry as possible, but keep watch on the weather. If it gets worse, then we have got to do more, but respond in a measured way, in a calibrated way, and look, even in the darkest cloud, for silver linings which may open up new opportunities for us, which means not slowing down our restructuring because of the problems we are facing, but

Column: 1748

pressing on so that when the weather clears up again, we will be well positioned and we will be ahead.

    Mr Gerard Ee (Nominated Member): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, with the scenario just painted and the forecast on value added, factories of the future, and so forth, could the Minister reflect on the future of SMEs in Singapore to face such competition?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, SMEs will face a challenge because those who are in traditional industries will face the cold wind of competition. If you look around the housing estates, many of our small shops are facing severe challenges because the supermarkets, the big departmental stores, the franchisees are coming in. For those who are unable to upgrade, partly because they are getting on in years and their children are not prepared to take over their parents' businesses, or because of bad luck, or because of inertia, then we have a package which MND had announced recently to help them exit. For those who are prepared to try, we will make every effort to help them.

    We are now looking at how we may want to reorganise PSB and TDB to give a stronger focus to entrepreneurial development, especially among our SMEs. For those who are prepared to try, there will be all kinds of packages available to help them along. And those who have decided that they want to call it a day, I think we will help them exit. But this varies from sector to sector. We have many discussions with various sectors and there are some who have done well, despite all the problems. If you look at, say, the food industry, it is quite interesting the way the food industry is being restructured now. A lot of the otak otak, nasi lemak and fishball that we are getting in the shops now are all made in factories. It is a very efficient supply chain. And there are others who are unable to make the adjustment, so they go through a prolonged period of difficulty. But this is a large subject, we have talked about it, and we will continue to talk about it. We will institute in the coming months more programmes to help SMEs.

Column: 1749



    Mr Hawazi Daipi (Sembawang): Sir, does the Minister see any possibility at all in helping to attract some of the companies to remain in Singapore, ie, companies which are likely to move over to other countries which offer lower cost structure, or attract some of these companies to come to Singapore? I ask this because there could be people who, for some reason, could only take up very rudimentary skills through all the schemes that we offer.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: In fact, we work very hard on this. When companies indicate that they have difficulties with their cost structure and are thinking of relocating, usually they alert EDB and we will try and sit down with them to work out a package to help them restructure and try to facilitate their remaining on in Singapore. And even if they have got to leave Singapore, we will try to encourage them to leave behind in Singapore the higher value elements. Sometimes, we succeed, but not always. But we have got to keep working at this and provide an environment which, despite higher labour costs and higher land costs, yields greater system efficiency. And one area in which we have a clear advantage is the fact that we provide a hassle-free environment. We tell them, at the outset, that we will make sure that they are able to find the skills that they need and, if these skills are not available in Singapore, they can import them from anywhere in the world in order to maintain their operation here.

    We have one further advantage which should become more and more important in the coming years, which is the way we protect intellectual property rights and provide for their enforcement. This involves the judiciary, the AG's Chambers, the police, the whole infrastructure. It would eventually extend into the life sciences. And if we can be the most secure base in Asia for intellectual property, then I think many of the higher value activities will remain here. Take, for instance, Glaxo. They set up a factory in Suzhou which had to be mothballed because of intellectual property problems in China. It will take a long time for China to work through all the laws and

Column: 1750

enforcement procedures. But in the meantime, if they have got something sensitive, if they have got secrets to protect and if they have got particular codes which contain most of the value of the product, they will put them in Singapore. And the key is running a system which is efficient, a labour market which is highly flexible and an access to talent which is global. This is very important. Then when they come here, they will be assured. No businessman wants to plonk a significant investment in a place where, after they have put in the money, they face all kinds of obstacles and have got to fight them at every turn.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Minister has spoken about the rising unemployment and he expects it to rise further. May I ask the Minister what message his Government has got at the moment for workers who are being retrenched, or has the Government got no message at all, and particularly, is the Government prepared to see that our workers are not retrenched first before foreign workers are retrenched, which is a step that is being taken by the Malaysian government?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, all of us, as Members of Parliament, meet our voters and in the last few months, we could sense the change in the economic climate on the ground. At our meet-the-people sessions, many more are coming forward either with financial difficulties, worried about their jobs, or have lost their jobs. The problem is not yet very serious. But we are beginning to see it and it is likely to become more serious in the coming months. I would say our response must be on a broad front. First, make sure that the children's education is not affected. I believe we have a whole slew of scholarships and bursaries available to make sure that they are looked after. With health care, housing, the basics, the safety net will always be there. Then those who are without jobs, how do we help them retrain? MOM has got a labour exchange. (Statement by the Deputy Prime Minister)

    Many Singaporeans are understandably concerned about how bank consolidation might affect them. I appreciate their concerns. Let me explain why consolidation is unavoidable for the banking industry and more importantly is good for Singapore, and let me also explain how some of these concerns can be met.

Importance of Consolidation

    The banking industry is undergoing dramatic change everywhere. Unless the local banks upgrade themselves and keep up with the changes, they will become weak and marginalised, even in Singapore. Consolidation is a worldwide trend in banking, and is an essential element in the upgrading of local banks.

    In the past, the local banks could maintain their market positions and grow organically as the economy grew year by year, so long as they conducted their business prudently and avoided mishaps. But that was in a different environment, with limited foreign competition and a slow pace of innovation. Today competition is fierce and technology is changing rapidly. The industry is characterised by large economies of scale, putting a high premium on size. Investors demand that banks earn competitive returns, or else they will punish their share prices. Small banks simply do not have the resources to compete. They are unable to out-perform larger banks, either in the quality of service or in returns to shareholders.

    Even large international banks, many times the size of Singapore banks, feel

Column: 1782

the pressure to grow still larger. They have been merging among themselves, becoming what analysts call "Godzilla" banks. Deutsche Bank, at one time among the largest banks in the world, feels the need for a merger partner. Smaller banks throughout the world have merged with each other or have been swallowed by these Godzilla banks. The largest of the Godzilla banks is Citigroup, with an estimated 100 million customers worldwide. HSBC has 20 million, and ABN Amro 13.5 million. Their size enables them to invest billions of dollars in the latest technology and sophisticated systems. Because they can spread these costs over millions of customers world-wide, they can efficiently deliver a wide-range of customised products at low unit costs.

    The result is fewer but much bigger banks. Over the past decade, the number of banks in small countries has fallen significantly. In Sweden, the number fell by 75%. Switzerland, with a GDP and a population about twice our size, now has only two big banks - UBS and Credit Suisse - both world-class players. The Netherlands, four times as big as Singapore, has three - ABN-Amro, Rabobank and ING, plus Fortis which is partially Belgian. Australia, which is slightly bigger than the Netherlands, also has four big banks.

    Singapore's economy is 1/4 the size of Australia's. Singapore cannot support five local banks. Our biggest bank DBS, even after the merger with POSBank, is ranked only 115th in the world by asset size. The logic of Singapore's circumstances is inescapable: if we want strong banks, then they have to be big banks, and if they are to be big banks, then they must consolidate.

    Any merger between the local banks will not create a Godzilla bank. The merged entity will still be small by international standards. What the Godzillas are doing involves scale economies that the local banks cannot get anywhere close to. Some might argue therefore that whether the local banks are very small or just small makes no difference to their ability to

Column: 1783

Local consolidation can create viable Singapore banks that can hold their own in the local market without Government protection, and compete in selected foreign markets. They will not compete globally with the big players, nor can they compete in every product line. But they should be strong enough to avoid being completely marginalised, at home and in Asia. They will be in a position to expand through careful acquisitions abroad over time, rather than be left with no choice but eventually be acquired by foreign players.
